WorkItem.Description:
The first big reason I moved to MVC, loved it, and would never go back to webforms, is that MVC doesn't get in my way. I think that if you don't care about the quality of your output, you are throwing away at least 60% of the power of MVC.

Check out your pages with the w3c markup validator: you declare them as xhtml 1.0 strict but they don't validate. This is the validation for the homepage:
http://validator.w3.org/check?verbose=1&uri=http%3A%2F%2Fnerddinner.com%2F

14 errors. Getting the site to validate is but the first step to its quality. You should also consider:

- Using unobtrousive javascript, having nothing on the site depending on it (everything must be usable even without js)
- Using proper media attributes in your css to avoid screen stylesheet from being used on handheld devices or printers
- Checking your site for at least basic accessibility rules

Comments.Message: Cool. I fixed the validation, so we're XHTML Strict now. Any other suggestions?
